citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the licensee does not have records of acquisition for two adult canaries that were added to the
inventory since the last inspection.
Records containing the required information for animals disposed of, or acquired for, use in regulated activities (including
those offspring born on premises) are necessary to accurately track animals to ensure their humane care and use. The
licensee must make and maintain records of the inventory, acquisition and disposition of all animals which fully and
correctly disclose the required information.
TO BE CORRECTED BY OCTOBER 2, 2024

The indoor portion of the primary enclosure housing one adult male ring-tailed lemur named "Maurice" has rusted areas of
metal, some of which have rusted through on the lower metal bars to produce holes and sharp points.
Rusted metal is porous and cannot be easily cleaned and sanitized; rusted-through metal creates sharp points that can
injure the animals. The licensee must ensure that any surfaces that come in contact with non-human primates are free of
excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitation or that affects the structural strength of the surfaces, and
that all surfaces are free of jagged edges or sharp points.
TO BE CORRECTED BY OCTOBER 2, 2024

In the enclosure housing one adult, male African crested porcupine there is an area of approximately eight square feet
under a bridge feature where the animal has dug and exposed the buried wire grid paneling, creating spaces large
enough for his feet to pass through.
Exposed wire with large holes under an animal can result in injury or entrapment. A system of facility monitoring should be
in place to ensure all enclosures are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from illness
or injury.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Accumulations of mouse droppings are seen in numerous places on the floor throughout the indoor portions of the facility,
including the commissary area. Food dishes and plastic storage totes in this area also had mouse feces in and on them.
Two adult feral mice were seen running in the commissary and aviary room. Additionally, a food prep area in the
commissary has an area on the floor under the sink that has accumulated food waste and other wet debris, with
cockroaches present.
Wild rodents and cockroaches can harbor or spread parasites and disease-causing microbes that can contaminate food
and food prep areas and cause injury or illness to the animals. The licensee must establish and maintain a safe and
effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests so as to promote the health
and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. Insecticides, chemical agents, or other
pest control products that may be harmful to the birds must not be applied to primary enclosures and other bird contact
surfaces unless the application is consistent with manufacturer recommendations or otherwise approved for use and does
not harm birds.
TO BE CORRECTED BY OCTOBER 16, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
At the time of inspection, the licensee does not have records of acquisition for two adult canaries that were added to the 
inventory since the last inspection.  
Records containing the required information for animals disposed of, or acquired for, use in regulated activities (including 
those offspring born on premises) are necessary to accurately track animals to ensure their humane care and use. The 
licensee must make and maintain records of the inventory, acquisition and disposition of all animals which fully and 
correctly disclose the required information. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY OCTOBER 2, 2024 
3.80(a)(2)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The indoor portion of the primary enclosure housing one adult male ring-tailed lemur named "Maurice" has rusted areas of 
metal, some of which have rusted through on the lower metal bars to produce holes and sharp points.  
Rusted metal is porous and cannot be easily cleaned and sanitized; rusted-through metal creates sharp points that can 
injure the animals. The licensee must ensure that any surfaces that come in contact with non-human primates are free of 
excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitation or that affects the structural strength of the surfaces, and 
that all surfaces are free of jagged edges or sharp points.  
TO BE CORRECTED BY OCTOBER 2, 2024 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
In the enclosure housing one adult, male African crested porcupine there is an area of approximately eight square feet 
under a bridge feature where the animal has dug and exposed the buried wire grid paneling, creating spaces large 
enough for his feet to pass through. 
Exposed wire with large holes under an animal can result in injury or entrapment. A system of facility monitoring should be 
in place to ensure all enclosures are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from illness 
or injury. 
3.158(d)

Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Accumulations of mouse droppings are seen in numerous places on the floor throughout the indoor portions of the facility, 
including the commissary area. Food dishes and plastic storage totes in this area also had mouse feces in and on them. 
Two adult feral mice were seen running in the commissary and aviary room. Additionally, a food prep area in the 
commissary has an area on the floor under the sink that has accumulated food waste and other wet debris, with 
cockroaches present. 
Wild rodents and cockroaches can harbor or spread parasites and disease-causing microbes that can contaminate food 
and food prep areas and cause injury or illness to the animals. The licensee must establish and maintain a safe and 
effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests so as to promote the health 
and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. Insecticides, chemical agents, or other 
pest control products that may be harmful to the birds must not be applied to primary enclosures and other bird contact 
surfaces unless the application is consistent with manufacturer recommendations or otherwise approved for use and does 
not harm birds.  
TO BE CORRECTED BY OCTOBER 16, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
